posts.title: Chain Complex
posts.excerpt: Homological algebra初步的初步. Chain complex的定义以及一些性质. 再没有tikz-cd我要死了.
posts.text: Homological algebra初步的初步. Chain complex的定义以及一些性质. 再没有tikz-cd我要死了. Chain Complex Definition 1. A chain complex (A,d)(A,d)(A,d) in an addicitive category A\mathcal{A}A is a family of objects and morphisms: $$\cdots\xrightarrow{}A_{n+1}\xrightarrow{d_{n+1}}A_{n}\xrightarrow{d_{n}}A_{n-1}\xrightarrow{}\cdots$$ with di−1∘di=0d_{i-1}\circ d_{i}=0di−1​∘di​=0 for all i∈Zi\in\mathbb{Z}i∈Z. The family ddd as well as its components dnd_{n}dn​ is called the differential of boundary morphism. Definition 2. A morphism of complexes f:(A,dA)→(B,dB)f:(A,d^{A})\to (B,d^{B})f:(A,dA)→(B,dB) is a family of morphisms: fn:An→Bnf_{n}:A_{n}\to B_{n}fn​:An​→Bn​, n∈Zn\in \mathbb{Z}n∈Z s.t. the diagram commutes. To simplify the notation, we always write it as fdA=dBffd^{A}=d^{B}ffdA=dBf. The category of chain complex in A\mathcal{A}A is denoted Ch(A)\mathrm{Ch}(\mathcal{A})Ch(A). The full subcategory whose objects are of the form $$\cdots\xrightarrow{}A_{1}\xrightarrow{}A_{0}\xrightarrow{}0\xrightarrow{}\cdots$$ is denoted Ch≥0(A)\mathrm{Ch}_{\geq 0}(\mathcal{A})Ch≥0​(A). If A\mathcal{A}A is an addicitive category, it’s easy to verify Ch(A)\mathrm{Ch}(\mathcal{A})Ch(A) is an abelian category. Proposition 1. For morphism f:A→Bf:A\to Bf:A→B, fff is injective(resp. surjective) if and only if fn:An→Bnf_{n}:A_{n}\to B_{n}fn​:An​→Bn​ is injective(resp. surjective) for all nnn. Proof. Obvious. ◻ Proposition 2. A→fB→gCA\xrightarrow{f}B\xrightarrow{g}CAf​Bg​C is exact if and only if for all nnn, An→fnBn→gnCnA_{n}\xrightarrow{f_{n}}B_{n}\xrightarrow{g_{n}}C_{n}An​fn​​Bn​gn​​Cn​ are exact. Proof. Obvious. ◻ Homology Definition 3. Let AAA be a chain complex, the nnn-th homology group of AAA is defined to be Hn(A)=Kerdn/Imdn+1H_{n}(A)=\mathrm{Ker}d_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}Hn​(A)=Kerdn​/Imdn+1​. From the diagram we can derive H(fn):Hn(A)→Hn(B)H(f_{n}):H_{n}(A)\to H_{n}(B)H(fn​):Hn​(A)→Hn​(B) by fn:KerdnA→KerdnBf_{n}:\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{A}\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{B}fn​:KerdnA​→KerdnB​ and fn:Imdn+1A→Imdn+1Bf_{n}:\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}\to \mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{B}fn​:Imdn+1A​→Imdn+1B​ and the universal property of quotient. So we see actually H(−)H(-)H(−) is a functor Hn(−):Ch(A)→AH_{n}(-):\mathrm{Ch}(\mathcal{A})\to \mathcal{A}Hn​(−):Ch(A)→A. Often, in particular in applications to topology, elements of chain complex AnA_{n}An​ are called nnn-chains; elements of Kerdn\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}Kerdn​ are called nnn-cycles and Kerdn\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}Kerdn​ is written Zn=Zn(A)Z_n = Z_n(A)Zn​=Zn​(A); elements of Imdn+1\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}Imdn+1​ are called nnn-boundaries and Imdn+1\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}Imdn+1​ is written Bn=Bn(A)B_n = B_n(A)Bn​=Bn​(A). Two nnn-cycles which determine the same element in Hn(A)H_n(A)Hn​(A) are called homologous. The element of Hn(A)H_n(A)Hn​(A) determined by the nnn-cycle ccc is called the homology class of ccc, and is denoted by [c][c][c]. Cochain Complex Definition 4. A chain complex (A,d)(A,d)(A,d) in an addicitive category A\mathcal{A}A is a family of objects and morphisms: ⋯→An−1→dn−1An→dnAn+1→⋯\cdots\xrightarrow{}A^{n-1}\xrightarrow{d_{n-1}}A^{n}\xrightarrow{d^{n}}A^{n+1}\xrightarrow{}\cdots ⋯​An−1dn−1​​Andn​An+1​⋯ with di∘di+1=0d^{i}\circ d^{i+1}=0di∘di+1=0 for all i∈Zi\in\mathbb{Z}i∈Z. The morphisms and cohomology functor is defined similarly. For a chain complex A=(An,dnA)A=(A_{n},d_{n}^{A})A=(An​,dnA​), we can obtain a cochain complex B=(Bn,dBn)B=(B^{n},d^{n}_{B})B=(Bn,dBn​) by setting Bn=A−nB^{n}=A_{-n}Bn=A−n​ and dBn=d−nAd^{n}_{B}=d_{-n}^{A}dBn​=d−nA​. Long Exact Sequence Theorem Lemma 1 (Snake lemma). Let AAA be an abelian category. Let be a commutative diagram with exact rows. There exists a unique morphism δ:Kerγ→Cokerα\delta:\mathrm{Ker}\gamma\to \mathrm{Coker}\alphaδ:Kerγ→Cokerα s.t. the diagram commutes, where π′\pi'π′, π\piπ are the canonical projections and τ\tauτ, τ′\tau'τ′ are the canonical injections. The induced sequence $$\mathrm{Ker}\alpha\xrightarrow{f’}\mathrm{Ker}\alpha\xrightarrow{f’}\mathrm{Ker}\beta\xrightarrow{g’}\mathrm{Ker}\gamma\xrightarrow{\delta}\mathrm{Coker}\alpha\xrightarrow{k’}\mathrm{Coker}\beta\xrightarrow{l’}\mathrm{Coker}\gamma$$ is exact. If fff is injective the so is f′f'f′, and if lll is surjective then so is l′l'l′. Proof. See 010H. ◻ Theorem 1 (Long exact seq.). Given a short exact seq. of chain complexes 0→A→fB→gC→00\xrightarrow{}A\xrightarrow{f}B\xrightarrow{g}C\xrightarrow{}00​Af​Bg​C​0, there are connecting morphisms δn:Hn(C)→Hn−1(A)\delta_{n}:H_{n}(C)\to H_{n-1}(A)δn​:Hn​(C)→Hn−1​(A) s.t. $$\cdots\xrightarrow{} H_{n}(A)\xrightarrow{}H_{n}(B)\xrightarrow{}H_{n}( C)\xrightarrow{\delta_{n}}H_{n-1}(A)\xrightarrow{}H_{n-1}(B)\xrightarrow{}H_{n-1}( C)\xrightarrow{}\cdots$$ is an exact sequence. Proof. Consider exact sequence: 0→An→fnBn→gnCn→00\xrightarrow{}A_{n}\xrightarrow{f_{n}}B_{n}\xrightarrow{g_{n}}C_{n}\xrightarrow{}0 0​An​fn​​Bn​gn​​Cn​​0 Since fnf_{n}fn​ takes Imdn+1A\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}Imdn+1A​ to Imdn+1B\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{B}Imdn+1B​, gng_{n}gn​ takes Imdn+1B\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{B}Imdn+1B​ to Imdn+1C\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{ C}Imdn+1C​, we have the sequence $$A_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}\xrightarrow{\bar{f_{n}}} B_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{B}\xrightarrow{\bar{g_{n}}}C_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{ C}$$ exact. Since gng_{n}gn​ surjective, gnˉ\bar{g_{n}}gn​ˉ​ is also surjective. We have the exact sequence $$A_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}\xrightarrow{\bar{f_{n}}} B_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{B}\xrightarrow{\bar{g_{n}}}C_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{ C}\xrightarrow{}0$$ Similarly, 0→KerdnA→KerdnB→KerdnC0\xrightarrow{}\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{A}\xrightarrow{}\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{B}\xrightarrow{}\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{C} 0​KerdnA​​KerdnB​​KerdnC​ is an exact sequence. Since dn∘dn+1=0d_{n}\circ d_{n+1}=0dn​∘dn+1​=0, we have dn+1Ad_{n+1}^{A}dn+1A​ restric to An/Imdn+1AA_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}An​/Imdn+1A​ to KerdnA\mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{A}KerdnA​, we ge the commutative diagram: Ker(dnA:An/Imdn+1A→KerdnA)=Hn(A)\mathrm{Ker}(d_{n}^{A}:A_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{A})=H_{n}(A)Ker(dnA​:An​/Imdn+1A​→KerdnA​)=Hn​(A) and Coker(dnA:An/Imdn+1A→KerdnA)=Hn−1(A)\mathrm{Coker}(d_{n}^{A}:A_{n} /\mathrm{Im}d_{n+1}^{A}\to \mathrm{Ker}d_{n}^{A})=H_{n-1}(A)Coker(dnA​:An​/Imdn+1A​→KerdnA​)=Hn−1​(A), by snake lemma, it induces $$\cdots\xrightarrow{} H_{n}(A)\xrightarrow{}H_{n}(B)\xrightarrow{}H_{n}( C)\xrightarrow{\delta_{n}}H_{n-1}(A)\xrightarrow{}H_{n-1}(B)\xrightarrow{}H_{n-1}( C)\xrightarrow{}\cdots$$ ◻ Similarly result for cochain. For any [c]∈Hn(C)[c]\in H_{n}(C)[c]∈Hn​(C), ∃b∈Bn\exists b\in B_{n}∃b∈Bn​ s.t. gn(b)=cg_{n}(b)=cgn​(b)=c. Then gn−1(dnB(b))=dnC(gn(b))g_{n-1}(d_{n}^{B}(b))=d_{n}^{C}(g_{n}(b))gn−1​(dnB​(b))=dnC​(gn​(b)). ∃a∈An−1\exists a\in A_{n-1}∃a∈An−1​ with fn−1(a)=dnB(b)f_{n-1}(a)=d_{n}^{B}(b)fn−1​(a)=dnB​(b). The map δ\deltaδ takes [c][c][c] to [a][a][a].

posts.title: An example of direct sum but not split exact sequence
posts.excerpt: 一个含有direct sum的short exact sequence但不是split short exact sequence的例子.
posts.text: 一个含有direct sum的short exact sequence但不是split short exact sequence的例子. Recall the definition of split exact sequence We say a short exact sequence split iff. it is isomorphic to the exact sequence 0→A→fA⊕B→gB→00\xrightarrow{} A\xrightarrow{f} A\oplus B \xrightarrow{g} B\xrightarrow{}0 0​Af​A⊕Bg​B​0 where fff is the inclusion of the first component and ggg is the projection onto the second component. 注意到split exact seq 在定义里要求fff 和ggg 分别是到A⊕BA\oplus BA⊕B的每一个component, 是否有例子使得一般的short exact seq s.t. 0→A→fA⊕B→gB→00\xrightarrow{} A\xrightarrow{f} A\oplus B \xrightarrow{g} B\xrightarrow{}00​Af​A⊕Bg​B​0 但是不是exact seq? 答案是Yes. Example of non split exact sequence Consider the short exact sequence 0→Z/2Z→fZ/4Z→gZ/2Z→00\xrightarrow{} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{f} \mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z} \xrightarrow{g} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{}0 0​Z/2Zf​Z/4Zg​Z/2Z​0 where fff is the inclusion of the subgroup generated by 2, so f(1)=2f(1) = 2f(1)=2, and ggg is the quotient onto that subgroup, meaning g(1)=1g(1) = 1g(1)=1. This is not a split short exact sequence(obviously). Consider M⨁N(Z/2Z⊕Z/4Z)M\bigoplus\limits_{\mathbb{N}}(\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\oplus\mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z})MN⨁​(Z/2Z⊕Z/4Z). Thus the exact seq 0→Z/2Z→hZ/4Z⊕M→iZ/2Z⊕M→00\xrightarrow{} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{h} \mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z}\oplus M \xrightarrow{i} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\oplus M\xrightarrow{}0 0​Z/2Zh​Z/4Z⊕Mi​Z/2Z⊕M​0 with h(a)=(f(a),0)h(a) = (f(a), 0)h(a)=(f(a),0) and t(a,m)=(g(a),m)t(a, m) = (g(a), m)t(a,m)=(g(a),m) is exact. Z/4Z⊕M\mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z}\oplus MZ/4Z⊕M is isomorphic to (Z/2Z)⊕(Z/2Z⊕M)(\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z})\oplus(\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\oplus M)(Z/2Z)⊕(Z/2Z⊕M). However, this is not a split exact seq since 0→Z/2Z→hZ/4Z⊕M→iZ/2Z⊕M→00\xrightarrow{} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{h} \mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z}\oplus M \xrightarrow{i} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\oplus M\xrightarrow{}0 0​Z/2Zh​Z/4Z⊕Mi​Z/2Z⊕M​0 will give a exact seq $$0\xrightarrow{} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{f} \mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z} \xrightarrow{g} \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\xrightarrow{}0$$ which is not split exact.
